Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund new and replacement instrumentation on the R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 168 foot general purpose research vessel operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The R/V Atlantic Explorer is a general-purpose research ship owned and operated by the
Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS). BIOS is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research. The RV Atlantic Explorer has 149 days funded in 2013, all of which are for NSF. With this proposal, BIOS provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

Fume Hood $20,075
Transmissometer $7,600
Van Veen Grab $5,525
$33,200


Broader Impacts

The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two of the Proposal Guidelines. They provide infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2013 Oceanographic Instrumentation R/V Atlantic Explorer

This award, in the amount of $27,675, was used to purchase the instrumentation, upgrades and equipment described below for installation on board the R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 170 ft. general purpose research vessel operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the University­National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not­for profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research.

With this award, BIOS acquired the following Oceanographic Instrumentation Equipment.

1) WetLabs Deep C-Star Transmissometer $7,600

The Wet Labs Transmissometer was purchased and placed into service in July 2013. This deep rated transmissometer is a core component of the R/V Atlantic Explorer’s shared-use CTD instrumentation package. This package of instruments is the workhorse of oceanographic research. The CTD instrument package is regularly lowered to the bottom of the ocean, providing real-time physical, chemical, biological, and optical properties of the subsea environment to researchers aboard the vessel. This data and real-time interaction allows the researchers to visualize and quantify the dynamics of the ocean and to precisely extract sea-water samples from specific depths of interest. The transmissometer is a critical component which provides calibrated information about the optical properties of the water, including turbidity and light transmissivity. The WetLabs Deep C-Star Transmissometer purchased through this award has a depth rating of 6,000m below the ocean’s surface, which means it can remain on the CTD package and provide this critical data on each deployment. This particular transmissometer entered into service in July 2013 and has performed extremely well in this role during the previous 3 years. This robust transmissometer works half the year, traversing the depths of the ocean, while sharing the duty with another transmissometer. It only gets a break while being sent back to WetLabs for its annual calibration and checkup, or resting topside as a ready spare, in the event the other transmissometer develops  a condition which renders it unfit to perform this arduous duty. Each of the two transmissometers that support the researchers aboard the R/V Atlantic Explorer make on average 200 trips into the depths of the ocean annually. All in all, the R/V Atlantic Explorer performed 250 CTD profiles in 2013, 419 in 2014, and another 296 in 2015. This unit was aboard the CTD package for half of those deployments. The transmissometer funded through this award has profiled the optical properties of the deep Atlantic Ocean over 600 times, as of today. Proper maintenance and care should keep this instrument in the game of supporting ocean researcher for years to come.               

This award provided a deep rated transmissometer which has proven to be an important and reliable data producer and will continue to support the demands of many NSF funded ocean research projects in the future.
